narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: learned basics of cryptography
I gained knowledge of basic cryptography and computer security including symmetric and assymetric cryptosystems, hash functions, authentication, and other crypto topics.
basic cryptography and security concepts, a little number theory

I learned how to reason effectively about cryptographic systems and many really cool cryptography schemes for sharing, distributing, and storing data securely. I also learned some really cool applications of number theory, such as how quadratic residues and polynomial interpolation can be in cryptography. (If you are scared of the big math words I just used, don't worry; Professor Fischer does a really great job explaining them.)
I learned about cryptography and its historical and practical applications, as well as how to construct cryptosystems, recognize their weaknesses, etc.
Crypto

Learned in depth knowledge about number theory relating to cryptographic methods along with a little more than a basic understanding of cryptography and differenty cryptographic schemes and the flaws with each of them along with how they devoloped.

This is a pretty broad cryptography course. The first couple weeks focuses on computer security in general, and there is discussion of the practical effects of bitcoin near the end, but mostly the course is about cryptographic algorithms and technical concepts. I would say I have a better idea of common cryptographic methods, and the ability to detect relatively straightforward flaws in proposed algorithms. I also learned about the possibility of using cryptography to perform tasks like oblivious transfer, which previously I didn't know was possible.
I learned a lot about cryptography and different cryptographic algorithms that are being used today.
I learned to critically analyze proposed cryptographic security schemes. I also learned various real protocols.

You will learn about various cryptosystems (classic ones - Caesar cipher, one-key, two-key), digital signatures, crypto hash functions, zero-knowledge proofs, a bit of blockchain, and an overview of the math behind these topics.
A comprehensive overview of cryptography, stretching from basic ciphers to the blockchain. Fundamentals of analyzing systems, finding weaknesses, and performing basic attacks.
Basic cryptography principles and encryption algorithms in theory rather than practice
Gained a good understanding of various encryption methods, secret-sharing schemes, and crypto-currencies.
this was a great overview of computer security. i know a great deal more about cryptography than before

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: this course sucked. he makes you come to lecture, talks really slowly, and then reads off the slides. I would never recommend this to another Yale student. The homework were not easy, not well covered in class, and the grading was extremely inconsistent. I also hated not having a real syllabus and not releasing the grading percentages (ie HW and exam weights) until after the final exam was unacceptable. Not to mention he said there would be a final paper and it ended up being a 3hr exam.

The slides and overall course materials were phenomenal in this course. My only issue was that the lectures could be dry at times and I would have loved to see more examples/application of the knowledge we were learning to break up the powerpoint. I also wish assignment answer keys were posted, because some questions remained unclear even after attending office hours.

loved this class. professor fischer is funny and tells fun anecdotes to teach concepts in class. i really liked it. I wish we had gone a little more in depth on some topics, but we went through so much stuff we probably did not have time.
The content is interesting, but the professor is not good.

Professor Fischer's explanation of the material and his slides are the best part of the course. The slides present the material in a very clear and easy-to-understand way that when combined with Professor Fischer's explanation, allows the material to be easily grasped. The first couple weeks seemed a bit slow but that was probably because I was already familiar with the content; the rest of the course was at a perfect pace.

The instruction method and slides were very clear and concise, and lecture was delivered well in addition to having all the lectures recorded for re-watching. Homework and exams were very fair and we were given ample time to complete them. Sometimes homework feedback was a little unclear.
Good class
The course was very informational. Minimal weaknesses.

The professor when I took it, Michael Fischer, clearly has deep knowledge of the subject matter and has also been following the latest developments/research. He is a fairly clear lecturer, though sometimes I thought he went through the math a little too quickly. Be warned though, unless you are extremely interested in cryptographic algorithms, the course can be a little dry. The format is mainly monotonous lecturing through a long series of slide decks. The psets were pretty helpful to cement conceptual understanding, and I enjoyed them. However, they varied widely in difficulty: sometimes they only took a single hour, sometimes they took 5. One week there wasn't even one assigned. Just be prepared for this variability.
This course gave an strong introduction to different cryptographic techniques, however at times the class was slow.
Professor Fischer is very nice and extremely organized. The only occasional frustrating thing was the grading could sometimes feel very picky or arbitrary with not a lot of feedback.

The class was a slideshow-based lecture, which helped convey information clearly over Zoom.  The availability of the slides and lecture recordings was also useful.  To increase participation, perhaps each lecture could have included a problem to solve in breakout rooms.  I also would have preferred if we covered fewer topics, but learned them more in depth.

The course, in its online format, feels not particularly interactive. It is a hard thing to address in large online classes, but I wish we had more opportunities to discuss topics with other students or work with the material beyond just homework and exams.

Strengths:
- Course material is interesting
- Professor is highly knowledgeable and willing to help students
- Lecture slides and assignments were well-organized and easy to follow
Weaknesses:
- Lectures could be kind of dry
Lectures composed largely of long streams of speech without pause; lecture slides were organized but it seemed rarely updated year to year.

The material presented in the course was interesting, but the presentation format was not. Lectures consisted of the professor going through 40 slides of word-dense slides with slides that we couldn't get to left as assigned reading for us to do later. Towards the end of the course I struggled to pay attention and wished I could skip lecture to later watch the recordings at 2x speed while I did something else. The professor didn't allow this, however, as daily attendance is required. Those who didn't have their video turned on in our zoom class meeting were cold-called in class, but our professor stopped doing this as often. The material of the course was pretty interesting, but I wish our professor had mixed up our regular 75 minute presentation of 40 lecture slides with something new here and there. The assignments were a strength of this course. I especially loved the programming assignments which weren't too time-consuming and required us to use the interfaces for various encryption/decryption methods.

One strength of the course is that Professor Fischer is very knowledgeable about Cryptography and was great at answering student's questions. There were many weaknesses of the course. The first weakness is that the class did not follow the syllabus. There were 2 exams, a midterm and a final, and 10 problem sets. Another weakness was the Teaching Assistant office hours as we were often mislead by the teaching assistant on how to solve the problem sets. We also did not know anything about the midterm in terms of content or format until we actually took the exam. It was scheduled a week before the date without any notice of there ever being a midterm so this threw off a lot of people's schedules.
well organized- lectures could be more interactive if the professor actually wants participation

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The lectures were way too slow and not engaging in the slightest. Maybe have more diagrams and pictures on slides
It was as good as it could be given the circumstances
standard practice of having online lectures. I liked that they were saved so we could rewatch again too.
The course was well fitted for COVID-19 pandemic, with recorded lectures, homework, and examination
All good

Professor Fischer originally made an effort to try to get everyone to participate in lecture, including by cold calling people. There was even a stated requirement that we were expected to speak at least once in every lecture. But people were very hesitant to speak, and since the class was 30+ people it was fairly unrealistic to expect everyone to participate while still getting through the lecture. He did ask us to turn our cameras on, though I'm not sure it really made me more engaged vs. any other live zoom lecture.

The class was a slideshow-based lecture, which helped convey information clearly over Zoom.  The availability of the slides and lecture recordings was also useful.  To increase participation, perhaps each lecture could have included a problem to solve in breakout rooms.
Having online recorded lectures was very helpful since it is difficult sometimes to always attend lectures.

Succeeded:
- I was able to see and hear the professor
Office hours were very helpful but classroom engagement could have been bettered through supplemental materials and resources.
recorded lectures were helpful

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: NO. This course did not have that much work, but was very dry, boring, and felt like I was not really learning anything
I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in a more mathematical approach to cryptography. If you're looking for a better less-technical overall introduction take CPSC257.
yes.
I would recommend the course but not professor fischer.

Absolutely! If you like the more theoretical or "mathy" side of CS, then you will probably find this course really interesting. The first couple weeks seemed a bit slow but that was probably because I was already familiar with the content. The last ~3/4ths of the course was really really interesting and used some really cool number theory. Professor Fischer does a good job presenting the cryptographic protocols used and the number theory needed to understand them.
This is a great course to learn about cryptosystems and their role in history, and is well set-up for learning the material especially in a virtual environment.

I would never recommend this course to another student, solely because of how disorganized it was. The professor didn't stick to the syllabus, the TA didn't know what had been covered in lecture, and a new grading assistant was brought in halfway through and completely changed how problem set grading worked. Although the coursework was interesting, the disorganization wasn't worth it. Do not take this course.
Yes
Yes if you are okay with some theoretical math at a basic level and want to learn anything in depth or even surface level about cryptography.

If you're interested in cryptography, go for it. It's a cool class and you do get to learn a lot of interesting things, and it isn't too much work. If you're a CS major, even if you're not incredibly interested in cryptography, this is a pretty decent elective. It definitely does get a little boring at times, but the lectures are pretty clear and I didn't find myself lost very often.
Yeah, it's a really interesting subject and fun to learn about and understand. Prof Fischer is really really nice and knows what he's talking about, though he's not always the most entertaining.

I think this course could be helpful to students who are interested in gaining a working knowledge of cryptography.  This class definitely emphasizes breadth over depth, so be prepared to cover a large number of topics.
Yes, if you're looking for a low-stakes introduction to cryptography and have some experience with C.
Yes; a good cs elective

I would recommend this as a good fifth course to add to your schedule if you're kind of low on time. The assignments are interesting and doable, and the lecture material is interesting, and if you can get through the lectures, this is a good class to take.

I would not recommend this course as there was a distinct lack of communication between the students, the professor, and the TA (and the grader who was different than the TA halfway through the semester) which led to some extremely stressful situations surrounding exams and assignments. The differences between the syllabus and the actual class were also very stressful.
yes great overview of cryptography - you cant learn it all from just online resources
